column4: anyone know how to uninstall  adobe flash or install using the yum or zipped version of the install file?
yum is the package manager used by Redhat/Fredora, IIRC
it probably isn't just called flash though. first do "aptitude search flash". Among the results, an "i" will tell you what you have installed
here is what it said for the line regarding flash: C   adobe-flashplugin               - Adobe Flash Player plugin version 10
do you have universe and multiverse enabled in your repositories?
yes last time i checked i did
have you already tried "sudo aptitude purge adobe-flashplugin"? If not, I suggest you do so
No, no, don't download and install directly! From the looks of that log, the purge fixed it. Now try "sudo aptitude update" and "sudo aptitude install adobe-flashplugin"
let aptitude take care of everything for you, it's your friend ;-)
same error or is it just saying it couldn't find the package?
nope differnet error ill go post it on pastebin

ChogyDan: Okay, I think we need to see exactly what you've got for flash-related packages in there. Try running "dpkg -L|grep -i flash" and let us know what it spits up (here if it's short, else pastebin)
ok, rictec, hang on a sec

ChogyDan, rictec: there was definitely mention of iceape-flashplugin earlier, though - if he tried to install that using dpkg it would definitely cause these kinds of problems, especially without having iceapepinstalled
something is wrong with that command
my bad! lower-case "l"
what letter is thast i cant tell, an i or a l
lower-case L
it says: rFR adobe-flashplugin                          10.0.32.18-1

sounds pretty messed up. for completeness, try "sudo dpkg --purge adobe-flashplugin". If successful,  do "sudo aptitude clean" and then "aptitude search flashplugin". if search turns it up, do "sudo aptitude install adobe-flashplugin".
and check your repositories. If you don't have restricted, enable it and update
if nothing else works, you can risk trying "sudo aptitude --full-resolver" but be warned that this is very forceful and could potentially do bad things to your installation
ummmmm
im kinda afraid of trying that
